awd_titl_txt: Single-Molecule Imaging of the Electrode/Solution Interface
awd_abstract_narration:
Many electrochemical reactions in the energy and environmental fields result in formation of gases at electrode surfaces. These reactions include facilitated formation of hydrogen and oxygen gases from the "splitting" of water, oxidation of methyl and ethyl alcohol in fuel cells, and charging and discharging events in batteries. Despite their importance, the initiation and growth of small gas bubbles on an electrode remain poorly understood due to a lack of proper analysis tools for imaging nanobubbles. To address this challenge, Professor Bo Zhang's laboratory at the University of Washington develops a fluorescence-based electrochemical method to image how and when gas nanobubbles are formed at the electrode/solution interface. The use of this method has the potential to promote the development of cheaper and more efficient facilitators (catalysts) for numerous electrochemical reactions in energy and environmental research. This work provides a set of integrated educational activities and a unique training opportunity for graduate, undergraduate, and high-school students to learn cutting-edge research in electrochemistry and microscopy.

With this award, the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program is funding Dr. Bo Zhang at the University of Washington to develop a new electroanalytical method to study nucleation and growth of gas nanobubbles at the electrode/solution interface. By single-molecule labeling and fluorescently imaging single nanobubbles on an electrode, this method yields spatially and temporally-resolved information about gas evolution processes on electrodes that is otherwise unobtainable using many other imaging techniques, such as scanning probe-based electrochemical microscopies. The ability to map nanobubble distribution may provide unique information about catalytic heterogeneity of electrode surfaces, which will help to understand and design new and better catalytic materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Electrocatalytic gas nucleation at the electrode/solution interface is a fundamentally important process for key technologies in energy and environmental research. This project(CHE-1904426) has supported the Zhang group’s research to further develop and use an analytical imaging tool to improve our understanding of gas nucleation and the gas/solution interface. More specifically, this project has enabled the Zhang group to label, fluorescently detect, and count single surface nanobubbles on an electrode. The establishment of this analytical tool also puts the Zhang group in a unique position to study interfacial processes at the gas/water interface on electrochemically-generated nanobubbles. Some of their recent results are as following.

In 2020, the Zhang group reported the successful imaging of both the hydrogen and oxygen nanobubbles in water electrolysis using single-molecule fluorescence microscopy (Anal. Chem. 2020, 92, 3682-3688.). The key aspect for this study was the use of a metal alloy film on an indium tin oxide (ITO) electrode as a catalyst for oxygen evolution. This is the first time that electrode-supported O2 nanobubbles are imaged with single-molecule fluorescence. In 2021, they demonstrated the ability to label and image H2 nanobubbles on an ITO electrode using Nile red as a solvatochromic dye (Anal. Chem. 2021, 93, 15315–15322). This work gives a direct evidence that the nanobubble’s air/water interface can act as a non-polar environment for promoting fluorescence emission of Nile red. In 2021 (Anal. Chem. 2021, 3, 457; Langmuir 2021, 37, 13816-13823), they published two papers reporting the use of single-molecule fluorescence to image nanobubble generation in the presence of surfactants. By imaging the rate of bubble formation at different potentials, their results show surfactant species promotes nanobubble nucleation on an electrode. Moreover, their recent data show electrostatics plays an important role in molecular adsorption on bubble surfaces.

Besides their work on nanobubbles, the Zhang group made tremendous progress on their electrochemical imaging work with massive bipolar electrode arrays (Anal. Chem. 2020, 92, 6748-6755; J. Electrochem. Soc. 2021, 168, 106502.).  Using photolithography, their team developed a large array of bipolar microelectrodes for imaging electrochemical events. Their imaging method uses electrochemiluminescence (ECL) as a useful means for optically monitoring electrochemical signals on >150,000 electrodes. The Zhang group also reported the collision, adhesion, and oxidation behavior of single Ag nanoparticles (NPs) on a polysulfide-modified gold microelectrode (J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2021, 143, 16154-16162). They found an ultrathin sulfurous layer can be formed on gold by sodium thiosulfate electro-oxidation, which can serve both as an adhesive interface for colliding NPs and as a preconcentrated reactive medium to oxidize Ag to form Ag2S. The knowledge learned from this study may benefit future NP collision systems for mechanistic studies in single-entity electrochemistry as well as designing ultrasensitive biochemical sensors.  

This project has supported five students toward their graduate research, Peter Defnet, Todd Anderson, Sam Barlow, Zhuoyu Peng, and Milo Suvira. Four of them graduated with their Ph.D. in this period. Dr. Samuel Barlow (PhD Dec 2020) is now a postdoc in Thomas Blanpied’s lab at the University of Maryland. Dr. Todd Anderson (PhD Sep 2021) is now a Senior Scientist at Tokyo Electron America. Dr. Peter Defnet (PhD Sep 2021) is now a Scientist at Intel. Dr. Zhuoyu Peng is an engineer at AutoCAD.

This project also supported the PI Bo Zhang in his role as a member of Board of Directors for Society for Electroanalytical Chemistry (SEAC) and later as the SEAC President for the 2019-2021 term. Zhang received the 2020 ACS DAC Award in Electrochemistry. Zhang is an active organizer for Pittcon and other national conferences. He worked with David Cliffel to organize a SEAC special issue for the J. Electrochem. Soc. and was one of the guest editors. Zhang delivered 6 invited departmental presentations and 7 invited conference presentations.

With their continued research efforts in developing new and powerful analytical tools to study the electrochemical interface, it is believed that their research will benefit the society in clean energy and environment research with better electrocatalysts.

 


Last Modified: 08/15/2022
Modified by: Bo Zhang
